title: 110_hr3678
content: The "Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007" changes the moratorium on internet taxes to extend until 2014. States that currently tax internet access are grandfathered in. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of "Internet access" for subsections (a) and (b) effective as of November 1, 2003. The Internet Tax Freedom Act was amended to define "Internet access" and provide exceptions for taxes on Internet access until June 30, 2008. The Internet Tax Freedom Act was amended to define "Internet access" and provide exceptions for taxes on Internet access until June 30, 2008. Thereafter, any tax applied to telecommunications services in a manner inconsistent with the Act before July 1, 2007, or subject to litigation seeking to enforce such tax in a conflicting manner, shall not draw any legislative construction inference. The Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007 clarified the definition of "Internet access" and provided exceptions for taxes on Internet access until June 30, 2008. No legislative construction inference shall be drawn from this subsection or the amendments made for any period prior to June 30, 2008, with respect to certain tax exceptions. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of Internet access as a service enabling users to connect to the Internet for content and services. The definition of Internet access under the Internet Tax Freedom Act is clarified to include telecommunications used to provide the service or enable users to access content, information, or services over the Internet. It also encompasses incidental services like home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and electronic storage capacity provided to users as part of the service. The definition of Internet access under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes telecommunications for accessing content, information, or services over the Internet. It also covers incidental services like home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and electronic storage capacity. This definition excludes voice, audio, or video programming, and other chargeable services utilizing Internet protocol. The definition of Internet access under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes telecommunications for accessing content, information, or services over the Internet, such as home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and electronic storage capacity. It excludes voice, audio, or video programming, and other chargeable services utilizing Internet protocol. The definition of Internet access under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes telecommunications services as defined in the Communications Act of 1934 and the Internal Revenue Code. A specific exception excludes State taxes on commercial activity from being considered a tax on Internet access. The term 'tax on Internet access' does not include State taxes expressly levied on commercial activity, modified gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income of the business by a State law specifically using one of these terms. The tax on Internet access excludes certain State taxes enacted between specific dates, replacing certain types of taxes, imposed broadly on business activity. The tax on Internet access excludes State taxes enacted between January 1, 1932 and January 1, 1936, imposed broadly on business activity and not discriminatory towards communication service providers. The State has the ability to modify taxes on business activities as long as it doesn't significantly limit the range of taxed activities or disqualify the tax. No conclusions should be drawn from this regarding previous tax applications. The State can modify business activity taxes without limiting the range of taxed activities or disqualifying the tax. No conclusions should be drawn regarding previous tax applications before November 1, 2007. SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to replace "telecommunications services" with "telecommunications" and to enable users to access content over the Internet. Additionally, section 1108 regarding voice services is removed. SEC. 6. SUNSET OF GRANDFATHER PROVISIONS. This section states that certain states will no longer be exempt from taxes on Internet access if they have repealed such taxes more than 24 months prior to the enactment of this provision. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will be effective on November 1, 2007, applying to existing and future taxes, except as noted in the Internet Tax Freedom Act.
